characters: A LARGE PICTURE OF CONOR, WITH HIS PHONE NUMBER AND THE
THE SCREEN GOES BLACK. AND THEN THE TITLE FADES UP
TWO FEMALE CASHIERS WORK SIDE BY SIDE.
FREEZE FRAME ON OUR LITTLE GIRL'S FACE
FROM INSIDE A CAR PARKED AT THE STORE
CHEST. AND HIS FACE IS TURNING AN ASHY, TERRIFYING GRAY.
HER DAD. HE HAS FALLEN TO HIS KNEES. HE'S CLUTCHING HIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float down through a serene, leafy park to the children's play area. There, in the sandbox, a BEAUTIFUL FIVE YEAR OLD GIRL plays among a group of kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a theory about how this all started...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIX YEAR OLD BOY approaches. He watches the little girl for a moment as she gently shapes her sand castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then - out of nowhere - THE LITTLE BOY PUSHES THE LITTLE GIRL DOWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you smell like dog poo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the other kids SNICKER at this brilliant one- liner. Our little girl's face turns red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so stupid just like dog poo! You're made of poo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, just to punctuate, he JUMPS ON THE SANDCASTLE, smashing it. Finally, our little girl starts to CRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our beautiful girl sits at a kitchen table with her MOM. She can only get out one syllable between big, wet sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made. (SOB)   Of. (SOB)   Dog. (SOB)   Poo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, do you know why that little boy did those things? And said those things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little girl shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he LIKES YOU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh - excuse me -- but what - the - HELL? Where did that rumor start? Because moms have been spreading it for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That little boy is doing those terrible things because he HAS A CRUSH ON YOU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see our little girl take this in, like she is just now beginning to understand the ways of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand what this means? We are all encouraged to believe that if a guy acts like a total jerk -- that means he likes you. Sure, that's a lesson that might serve us as five year olds, but many of us keep believing this advice well into adulthood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CUTE COLLEGE GIRL sits CRYING in front of her ANSWERING MACHINE, as her ROOMMATE looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, as we get older, we carry on this tradition of misreading the signals men send by encouraging our friends to do the same...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The machine evilly flashes 0 in the NEW MESSAGES window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Phi Delt so obviously liked you. I'm sure he just lost your number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HOT EXECUTIVE WOMAN stands in the office hallway, watching a SEXY MALE COLLEAGUE walk by. He does not give her a second glance. Her FEMALE SECRETARY looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not asking you out because he's intimidated by your professional success and emotional maturity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUNCH OF TWENTY-SOMETHINGS sipping cocktails. One of them is CRYING - smeared mascara, puffy eyes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the problem. He likes you TOO much. You're TOO pretty and awesome.        He can't handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me. It's because he's just getting out of a serious relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO MIDDLE AGED WOMEN work out on ellipticals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me. It's because he's never had a serious relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO HIPSTER JAPANESE GIRLS making their way through a crowded Tokyo department store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shigeru's inability to commit clearly stems from his failure to properly imprint on his mother during breast feeding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN weaves BANANA LEAVES with a FRIEND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he forgot your hut number.    Or didn't get enough approval from his father. Or was eaten by a giraffe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This last part seems to cheer up the pretty woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do we say this stuff to each other? Why do we tell each other these lies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible that it's because we're too scared, and it's too hard, to say the one obvious truth that's staring everyone in the face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIGI, pretty and approachable, sits in a booth at a hip Mt. Vernon date spot with CONOR, cute but holding onto his frat boy roots. They sip their near empty cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Janine told me you're a real estate agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But don't worry - not one of the cheesy ones who puts his headshot on bus benches and grocery carts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So just like on frisbees and notepads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor laughs.    Gigi smiles -- she's doing well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much classier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My thoughts exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sips her drink, and looks at Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder why Janine never thought of introducing us before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't know, I ummm -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their WAITRESS appears, cutting him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys ready for another round?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks to Gigi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want one more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if you do. But I mean, if you have to get going I totally ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi trails off. Conor considers this for a LONG MOMENT. We can see on Gigi's face that she knows that the outcome of this date hangs in the balance. It's an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm.    OK.   Sure. One more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi breathes a SIGH of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had Ketel and soda, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi NODS and SMILES, clearly flattered that Conor remembered her order. She scoots a little closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi and Conor HUG outside the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Conor, I had a really nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    It was really nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi waves flirtatiously and walks away, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around to look, and sees Conor TAKE HIS CELL PHONE OUT OF HIS POCKET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi TAKES HER CELL OUT OF HER PURSE and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's me. He's cute. I think it went well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sneaks another look over her shoulder to see Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I think he might me leaving me a message at home as - we - speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FREEZE FRAME ON GIGI, mid-step.    Then, THE IMAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONOR - also in FREEZE FRAME. The image UNFREEZES and we continue with Conor as he DIALS HIS CELL PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's me...I just wanted you to know that I was thinking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNA, hot in an earthy sort of way, heads down the aisle. She holds her cell phone in one hand - a BOTTLED WATER and a BAG OF SOY NUTS in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor, that's so nice.     Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anna gets to the checkout, there's one person ahead of her. He looks back to see her - he's BEN, good looking and supremely likeable. They share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to go ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead?   You've only got two things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at what he's got - a SIX PACK OF SIERRA NEVADA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've only got one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, technically it's six. And I'm still mulling over a gum purchase. So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps aside to let her go.   She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, let me call you right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up the phone and moves past Ben, hands her things to the EMOTIONLESS CASHIER. As he rings them up - she looks back at Ben - they SHARE ANOTHER LOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the cashier her ATM card - he swipes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Seriously. I just deposited money today. There's no way -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that. Let me check something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and rifles through a stack of papers, finally finding what he was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our "Sizzlin' Summer" promotion.     You're our 1000th customer in June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cashier reaches under the register and pulls out an IGLOO COOLER and hands it to Anna. She BEAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have that kind of manner? A joking manner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks to Ben.   She looks like she's about to burst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to god, this is the most exciting thing that's ever happened to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben can't tell if she's kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that sad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's - charming.     Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles wide, admiring her cooler.    Then -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, no. I can't accept this. You were here first. I didn't win at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you did. Trust me - it's fate.      You were meant to have that cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna throws her arms around him and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you SO MUCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben can't help but laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor enters his apartment.     ALEX sits on the couch watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.    How was the date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor heads for the kitchen, and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cable's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor returns from the kitchen with a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't hear the phone ring, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Anna gave me the "I'll call you right back."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I call back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'll call back and say that I'm going to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 9:30 PM?    Genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is genius. Because then I can say: "In case you were going to call me back - don't - 'cause I'll be sleeping."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds foolproof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor pulls off his jacket and tosses it next to a box - which contains about 50 FRISBEES. On each frisbee:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor dials his cell phone as he heads back to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We TILT up to find Anna and Ben. Anna looks at her phone, presses IGNORE and stashes it in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.   What was I saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you were telling me how you don't want to be like your mom and wake up and realize you didn't pursue your dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben opens his GUM and offers Anna a piece.     She takes and laughs, a bit embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I? Little intense for grocery store chatter. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK. I might even be able to help you out. There's a guy at my firm who has exclusively music clients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be - amazing.      What are you - like my savior?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna digs through her purse to find a piece of paper. She writes down her number, and holds it out to him. He looks at it, contemplating. He doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Look.      I'm married.   I don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do what? Help struggling singers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help hot Pilates instructing singers who happen to be very charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna takes the slip of paper and puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to give me your card? That's legit. I bet you're allowed to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   OK.   I guess that would be OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Anna and Ben talking.     They shake hands awkward and Ben HEADS TOWARDS US.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben gets in the car, bag in hand, and joins NEIL, 40, arty and kind looking, who's behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prospective client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can talk to a woman Neil.        It doesn't have to be like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil looks at him, smirk growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil starts the car and they pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil walks into a vast space. Nice art, a cozy yet architectural look - a cool place to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, babe.    You here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN over to a couch - where BETH is wrapped in a throw blanket, watching TV. She's got her hair in a messy bun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He joins her on the couch.        And sees that the TV is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Just got off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil gets up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some tea or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my baby sister.        She's getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. I've always liked that Devon guy. That's really great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth looks at him.    She doesn't look that happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you think it's great that they're getting married, but you never feel like we're going against nature or something by not getting married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits back down, puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going against nature is like that cat who started nursing that monkey. We're just two people who aren't married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth manages a weak smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually think the odds of having a successful relationship increase by not getting married. Look at my parents - all marriage got them was thirty two years of misery and joint checking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. I get that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I've always told you - I love you - and we don't need a marriage certificate to legitimize our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme get you some tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits. Beth starts to CRY, but quickly dries her tears, and forces herself to pull it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brick row house in an up and coming neighborhood - clearly under massive renovation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We make our way through rooms with plastic covering the doorways - until we find JANINE stepping into the hallway. She checks herself in a vintage mirror, straightens it a tad, then heads down the stairs to find GIGI, on her cell phone. Gigi slams it closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, so clearly he hasn't called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's away on business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sells real estate. In Baltimore. Staying in town is his business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine ponders this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, let me tell you - after the first time I went out with Ben, he didn't call me for eleven days. ELEVEN DAYS. And now he's like the world's best husband. That happens all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi manages a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?    Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You set me up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - you asked if I knew any guys and I gave Conor your number. That's not a set up. When I do a set up - I weigh pros and cons. I do my due diligence. All I know about Conor is he sold us this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi peers out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sold you a house in the ghetto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a neighborhood "in transition."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi makes a move for the phone, Janine stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he always hangs at Red Maple after work. Maybe I should do a little drive-by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, don't. He'll call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Gigi - panic seeping in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMBER, pretty if a little thick in the middle, sits in the courtyard of an office park in her work clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caller ID was the worst thing that's ever happened to me. Total invasion of my personal freedom. When a guy doesn't call me, it is my right - my duty even - to call him and hang up several thousand times. Or at least until his mother shouts at me in Albanian and blows a police whistle into the phone. I mean, calling and hanging up is an age old expression of love and frustration and too many wine coolers - and who is AT& f'ing T to take that away from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next thing you know, someone is going to ban me from sitting in my car in front of a guy's house, blaring "Where Is Your Heart" by Kelly Clarkson until his new stupid girlfriend comes outside and threatens to scratch my eyes out with her acrylics. I mean, a girl deserves freedom of expression, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pilates class. We pan down the row of mats, STUDENTS obediently doing The Mermaid. We finally land on Gigi's mat: Gigi manages to twist herself into a passable Mermaid - as her CELL PHONE lies in full view on her mat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shower is on, curtain pulled. A CELL PHONE RINGS. An ARM SHOOTS out of the shower and grabs it from the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, I gotta call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi lays in bed, her CELL PHONE right next to her head. One eye POPS OPEN, checks the phone, and closes again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typical, corporate style office. Walled off cubicles for the junior execs, outer offices for management.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi is in her cubicle. Janine, her friend and, we now learn, co-worker, sits on Gigi's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this was at the end of the date, or at the beginning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: End.   Why - does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. "Nice meeting you" at the beginning of the date is normal. "Nice meeting you" at the end could be a blow off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it was at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that's fine. He's gonna call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it was at the end.   Or maybe it was nice to meet me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - was it "nice meeting you" or "nice to meet you"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.   I can't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Nice to meet you" is OK. "Nice meeting you" is like "Do you want your receipt in the bag?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls look up to find BETH standing there, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember the days when you guys at least pretended to be working when I came in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth heads to her office.   Janine and Gigi follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine, how's the press release?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine, clearly organized, flips open her notebook:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beckon the baking to begin! McCormick, the flavor expert, introduces five fun filled flavors that will definitely delight dessert divas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi stifles a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe a shade heavy on the alliteration - but otherwise good. (to Gigi) Where are we with the company newsletter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so almost done with that. It's just been a little hard to focus on my article about the two sets of twins in market research, when the guy - who may or may not be the guy of my dreams - refuses to call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth looks at Gigi, more sympathetic friend than boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, after my first date with Neil, I called him. There are no rules anymore. Why should you have to wait for him to get off his ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sits at her desk, Janine standing by her side. She's got a few sheets of paper on her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi takes a deep breath, picks up the office phone and dials. Janine gives her a thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty standard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening to receiver) Yes!   Voicemail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi nods - it's all under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading off her paper) Hey, Conor. It's Gigi. I just thought, I hadn't heard from you and, I mean how stupid is it that a gal has got to wait for a guy's call anyway, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi laughs, but as she looks back to the notes, she seems confused. She turns to Janine, panicked, mouthing - "What does this say?". Janine looks - she's no help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearly ad-libbing) I mean, we're all equal, right? More than equal -- more women are accepted into law school now than men, and we do better in those police simulations where you can mistakenly shoot innocent people - (rifles through the pages) - I mean I don't know if you saw that Dateline - but women practically have penises now, right? (looks to Janine, helpless) Well, call me. This is Gigi. Call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi hangs up, unsure.   She looks to Janine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.    He's totally gonna call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi stares at the PHONE. Then she feigns disinterest in the phone. It still doesn't ring. Finally, she picks up the receiver to listen for a dial tone. And PANICS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAT?   How can there be no dial tone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She frantically jiggles the cord, then hears something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom? Is that you? I can't talk now. I'll call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, stares at the phone again. A look of DETERMINATION crosses her face. She dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine. It's me. Conor never called, so I'm on the precipice of staging a casual run-in at Red Maple. Pick up if you want to stop me. (beat, then really fast) ALRIGHT-I'M-INTERPRETING-YOUR-SILENCE-AS tacit-compliance-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi hurriedly hangs up, and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CROWDED, SCENEY restaurant/bar - with a giant red Japanese maple growing behind the bar (thus the name).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a THIN, BLACK CLAD HOSTESS as we wind through the throng of stylish twentysomethings at the bar to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A busy kitchen.   Off the kitchen a door leads to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX sits at a small, cluttered desk, rifling through some papers. Then, from the doorway:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock knock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks up to see KELLI ANN - Red Maple's hot hostess, standing in the doorway. She makes her way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.    Here we are. Same shift again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.    I make the schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured it was no coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans against the desk.     Alex keeps working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had fun the other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's amazing where 10 shots of Patron will get you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelli Ann laughs, then thinks - wait, was that nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway - I was thinking, maybe tonight after work...we could, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex stops what he's doing, looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Kelli Ann - what happened between us the other night was - fun. But we're way understaffed tonight - I even have to man the bar - and that's why I scheduled you. To work. So...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to work. Kelli Ann stands there, frozen. Alex can feel her eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we good here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelli Ann's face goes flush. She tries to hide it.    She backs up, puts on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    We're good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.   Alex exhales, goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back doorway leading to the alley, Alex stands chatting with TYRONE, 18, a busboy, who smokes a cigarette he holds just outside the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelli Ann approaches, trying to squeeze through, and ACCIDENTALLY (ON PURPOSE) SHOULDER BLOCKS ALEX. HARD. He has to take a step to catch his balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around to see what happened, but Kelli Ann keeps walking eyes front. He and Tyrone share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrone laughs as Alex shakes his head, not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi enters slowly, looking around, searching for Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to move toward the bar as she's met by Kelli Ann, who grabs a few menus and slaps on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you joining us for dinner or -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm meeting someone.       A guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh.    Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   Sorry. For dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi continues to scan the place, not paying attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm meeting someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you mentioned that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi finishes her visual tour of the room - no Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna wait at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi walks off.    Kelli Ann takes her place behind the hostess stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi grabs a stool with a good view of the door.     Alex now behind the bar, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's OK. I'm meeting someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex takes her in.       She's clearly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?    Got a hot date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you'd call it hot -- I mean this guy Conor and I have only been out the one time so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - Conor Barry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi is busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uhh, yeah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor's not coming in tonight. Did he forget he was supposed to meet you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See when I said "meeting someone" I guess that was kind of a broad term, kind of a wide interpretation of the word "meeting"-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I could just call him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! I mean, totally unnecessary. I mean, I actually was just - in the area - so I figured I'd just swing by and see if he was around - because - uhhh ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex waits, looking at Gigi, amused.    She is panicking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I uhh, had to return his --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi frantically searches her coat pockets - searching for something, anything - and finally fishes out A PEN. She looks at it - and decides to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pen. I had to return this - pen. He left this. So, I thought I should really return it before he - you know - (conspiratorially to Alex) -- freaks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks at her skeptically.   And then takes the PEN, and inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Frankel - Adult, Child and Geriatric Dentistry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not gonna judge about what may or may not be important to someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not even his dentist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really?   Then who's his dentist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi looks at Alex for a long moment, and finally folds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Gigi. Conor and I went out last week. And I just...I thought if I ran into him...I don't know. I'm gonna go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi struggles to get out quickly. Alex looks at her - holding her pen, looking quite frazzled - and softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Just - hang out for a second. Lemme buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi SMILES and sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. The bar is nearly empty. Alex is totaling receipts - and Gigi is still nursing a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you seem like a cool girl, so I'm just gonna be honest - Conor is never going to call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm a guy.   It's how we do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said it was nice meeting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if he said you were his favorite female since his mommy and Joanie Cunningham. Over a week went by - and he didn't call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe he called me and I didn't get the message. Or maybe he lost my number, or was out of town, or was hit by a cab, or his grandma died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe he just didn't call because he has no interest in seeing you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah but my friend Terri once went out with this guy who never called and she totally wrote him off - then like a year later she ran into him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friend Terri's an idiot.   And she's the exception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   But what if I'm the exception?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not. You're the rule. And the rule is - if a guy doesn't call you, he doesn't want to call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?     Always?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Always. I know what blowing off a woman looks like. I do it early and I do it often. Trust me - if a guy is treating you like he doesn't give a shit - - he doesn't. No exceptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me all of this? Aren't these man-secrets - like why men need to watch televised golf?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. You looked like you could really use the help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. You've given me a lot to think about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi comes in - carrying a MESSY HANDFUL OF PAPERS, with crazy hair and wearing the last outfit we saw her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was up all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please say you were working on the newsletter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's basically done.   But this is important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening with your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth comes out of her office and looks at Gigi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please come in my office before the others see that you have mini muffin stuck in your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi paces in front of Beth's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I figured it out. Remember when I went out with that notary public? And he cheated on me? And then Anastasia from upstairs told us that story about how her boyfriend cheated on her at the beginning - but then he totally changed and they're married and crazy in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that guy was a process server.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, notary. Anyway, the point is - Anastasia is the exception. Not the rule. We have to stop listening to these stories - because the rule is that most guys who cheat on you up front don't really care about you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi consults her crumpled pieces of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhibit A: Chad, the drummer who lived in his storage space. He only used me for rides, yet I continued to stalk him for most of 1998. Then there was Don, who broke up with me every Friday so he could have his weekends free. I was so delusional about our relationship that I referred to him as my husband to random people like my dental hygenist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all my friends would tell me stories about how things might work out with these dipshits because they knew someone who knew someone who dated a dipshit just like mine, and that girl ended up getting married and living happily ever after. But that's the exception. And we're not the exception - we're the rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sits down, spent.   But Beth has been listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. So let me see if I understand. What you're saying is that when people tell me about some girl they know who dated a guy for thirteen years, and then he finally married her -- that's the exception. And the rule is that guys - like Neil - who are with girls - like me - for seven years without getting married - are never getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is serious.   Gigi freezes, tries to backtrack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, no, no. That's not what I'm saying. This has absolutely nothing to do with you. I was just talking, you know, about me. Specifically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Beth, knowing it's about her, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and MARY, beautiful but doesn't know it, sit in side by side pedicure chairs. Anna holds a BUSINESS CARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is impossible not to like this guy. I'm pretty sure he was heavily flirting with me outside Eddie's, and then he tells me he's married. You'd think I'd be pissed, but I literally could not stop myself from liking him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize that. I keep trying to force myself to picture him in some church saying vows to some woman, and even that doesn't cool it off. What is my problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. There was this guy who worked in my dad's printing business. Married for fifteen years to a nice lady. And then he meets this woman at some church event. And he told my dad he just had never felt anything like it before. I mean, he had finally met the love of his life. So, he divorced his wife, and he's been with this other woman for 22 years and they are blissfully happy. I mean, what if you meet the love of your life - but you already married someone else? Are you supposed to pass them by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I'm calling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pulls her feet out of the pedicure bath, goes in a private corner, and dials her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ben.    This is Anna Marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Anna.   What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was just taking you up on your offer. You said you might know someone who could help me out and I thought we could discuss it -- over coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna waits for a response. On the other end she hears some rustling, some silence, definitely awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I just...I can't Anna. You seem great. It's just - I don't know. I should go. Take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna takes this in - STUNNED. She hangs up. Her eyes sting. She can't face Mary so she just stares at weird, bleached out photos of nails and HOLDS BACK THE TEARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, she looks at her cell phone and dials again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor opens the door to find Anna standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so psyched that you called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had sort of given up on you when you didn't call me back the other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know. I was just thinking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor buys it, and ushers her inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is stretched out with a wine glass in hand, feet in Conor's lap. He rubs her feet as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   Give me the categories again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are four. Sexy, smart, funny or cute. And each person can only be two. Like Sarah Jessica Parker is funny and sexy. Or Bill Clinton is sexy and smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that you are hot for Clinton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, which am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart and cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor smiles, happy for any compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   You're sexy. Very sexy.    And cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bangs him on the head with a pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Cute and sexy are in the looks column. No one wants to be in all one column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I sound like a jackass if I say you're all four. But you're so obviously all four. Especially sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits up, and moves to Conor. She looks at him, pulls him in for a nice, long HUG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. OK. I mean, you could just stay here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gives him a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   It's been a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's just - I'm fried.    Is that alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles and gets up. Conor reluctantly follows her to the door. She KISSES HIM ON THE LIPS, smiles, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth opens the door to find NEIL, standing on the couch in his socks, hanging a PAINTING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey babe, is this straight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you hanging that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I'd do it weeks ago.   You don't like it there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it there. But just - stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the image, isn't it? I didn't see it before, but - you're right - it totally looks like a sagging boob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to take it down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.     I want you stop doing anything nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a trick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I need you to stop being nice to me - unless you're gonna marry me after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.     It was just - I was just--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, you can't keep being nice to me and I can't keep pretending like this is something that it's not. We've been together over seven years. You know me. You either want to marry me or you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or there is the possibility that I just don't really believe in the concept of -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BULLSHIT! BULLSHIT! Bullshit for every woman who's been told by some guy that he doesn't believe in marriage just to see him turn around eight months later and marry some twenty four year old girl he met at the gym. Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth tries to hold back her tears. Neil looks stunned. He hops down off the couch and goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, where is all this coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the place that I have been hiding from you for the last five years because I didn't want to seem demanding, or clingy or psycho or whatever. So I never ask. But now I'm going to ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil looks at her.    She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ever going to marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth looks at Neil.    There is a long, painful SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMY sits with a sleeping baby in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was with Damon for six years. He asked me to marry him on the phone, because he's just so different and cool like that. Said he'd eventually get me a ring, which he didn't, but he did buy himself a ring because isn't that so hilarious and cool that the guy is wearing the ring? Then, my favorite part is, I stayed with him even after he took back his proposal, and introduced the idea of a "relation vacation." Isn't that a cute name? Let me explain the concept: it involves dating a girl from the time she's thirty two to the time she's thirty nine, possibly robbing her of the ability to bear children, and then, after all that, wanting to take a year off. And giving it a fun name that you can put on t-shirts. (looks at the baby, smiles) I left him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben, our married guy from the grocery store, sits on the floor in a barely furnished room, and dials his cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Anna. This is Ben. Look, I know it's been a little while since you called. I just - it took me by surprise. But I offered to help you with your career, and I don't see why I can't do that, right? So, give me a call. Maybe you can come by the office this week or something. Okay, take care. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben hangs up. And STARES INTO SPACE until THE DOOR OPENS TO REVEAL: JANINE. Gigi's co-worker. And Ben's WIFE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is CLEARLY STARTLED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit - you scared me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Everything's fine.   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down next to him, looks at him intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you smoking again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sweetie.    Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - you get jumpy when you smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben puts his arm around Janine, and pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not smoking. So, why don't we worry about what color we're gonna paint this room, instead of worrying about things that aren't happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine contentedly curls up to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know - I was thinking maybe - pink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink?   Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, at some point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine gives Ben a knowing look.   He gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure we're ready for this now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I mean, we could paint one room pink and one blue just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks at her and LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've already created the perfect family in this house, and we don't even have drywall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I know I promised we'd wait to talk about it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks at her, snuggled against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we're almost ready to start talking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine smiles CONTENTEDLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always liked the name Gisele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben LAUGHS.   She lets him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed, Federal Hill happy hour bar scene. Gigi and Janine stand, squeezed in among the after work crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JARRAD, early thirties, chats amiably with Gigi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ladies, I guess I have to get back to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go back to the office after happy hour? What's happy about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine and Gigi melt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'd love to call you sometime.    Do you have a card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi hands him her card with lightning speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here's my info.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jarrad hands Gigi HIS CARD as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look forward to hearing from you, Gigi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to head over to his BUDDIES.   Gigi is confused

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, wait -- how are we doing this? Are you hearing from me or am I getting a call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jarrad turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you'd love to call me, but then you said "look forward to hearing from you." See how that's kinda confusing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - we'll talk. We'll get in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to take off again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooopsie - you did it again. Very vague. You know what? Why don't we just say that you'll call me, and then we can skip all the nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jarrad just gives her a blank stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or I guess I could just call you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Gigi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off.   The girls watch him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't cyber-stalk him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi looks at the name on the card - JARRAD MONTROSE - and then - TEARS HIS BUSINESS CARD IN TWO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not calling him.    If he wants to see me - he'll call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that guy Alex really made an impression on you. Was he hot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   He was just -- right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Gigi, sipping her drink, full of optimism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The offices of Baltimore's gay weekly paper. The elevator opens - and in walks Mary, cheerful as always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow her down the hall as she ad-libs hellos to her co-workers. One thing becomes glaringly clear - SHE IS THE ONLY WOMAN WHO WORKS HERE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets to her desk and is descended upon by - BRUCE, NATHAN, and JOSHUA. All mid-20's. All gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at them, smiling, enjoying their impatience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He asked me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god!    He called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He emailed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Did he travel by carriage and leave his calling card with your lady in waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He MySpaced me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys all look skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. My slutty sister says MySpace is the new booty call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what am I supposed to do? Things have changed. People don't just meet organically anymore. If I want to make myself more attractive to the opposite sex, I don't go get a new haircut - I update my profile. That's just how it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys look at her, starting to understand.   Mary's PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles at the guys - they disperse as she picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ad sales - this is Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor sits on a bench, NEWSPAPER folded open on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's Conor. Anna's - uh - friend. Or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   So, did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta trust me. It's a burgeoning market. You're gonna make a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I hope so. But, like - did you have to put me on the page with the massage ads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was either that or on the page with the personals. I made a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. You're right.      Hey, have you talked to Anna lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor leaves the paper and gets up. He walks away, still on the phone, we STAY WITH THE NEWSPAPER AND WE PUSH IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNDER VARIOUS 1 INCH ADS FOR MASSEUSES, S&M and LEATH

dialogues.speaker: THE HOME FOR YOUR LIFESTYLE
dialogues.text: Under which is a picture of Conor, standing in front of a brick Tudor, a SOLD SIGN proudly displayed. In the background - TWO MEN look lovingly at their new home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAIGE, blonde and angelic, looks on as LAURA, CATHERINE, and Beth pull on matching coral dresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not understand how you got mom to sew all of these in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanted to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom told me she felt like an old Indonesian lady in a sweatshop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why again do you need to get married so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chug a beer, then. I want to see you chug a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in love, you assholes. That's what people do when they're in love - they get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone FREEZES.    And looks at BETH.   Big silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethie, you know I didn't mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK.    Neil and I are actually - done - anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is clearly news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell us?    You should have told us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to come over and have dinner with me and Steven and the kids tonight, OK? You can even stay over if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would she want to hang out with us and our husbands? Seriously, Beth, isn't that exactly what you want to avoid right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before Beth can even answer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what - if being in the wedding is too painful-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys, it's cool. I'm fine.    So I lost a little time. Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth grabs her purse and starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So not a big deal. You're still really young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you learned in that relationship is just gonna make the next one so much stronger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth exits, still wearing a half-sewn bridesmaid's dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasted so much time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew he was never gonna propose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben sits behind his desk, sifting through a pile of papers. We PAN around to Anna sitting across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's here somewhere. I spoke to George Lane in music, and he gave me this whole list of references for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cool.    You can call me when you find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear I didn't lure you here under false pretenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.   But a girl can dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at her and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're obviously too good of a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a LONG LOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you married, again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously. Why? It'll be good for me. Tell me how you decided that you could not be without this other woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd been together since college. She gave me an ultimatum: we get married or we break up. So, we got married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously?   You just caved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a dick if you date a girl for too long, and don't marry her. But you marry her, and then you're an asshole for marrying her before you're ready. Shit - I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really hot and I'm obviously attracted to you, but I guess the best I can do is eventually find this piece of paper, and call you, and hope I help in some small way with your career, and be happy about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine walks in from work to her construction site home. She peeks into the dining room, where she sees her CHERRY WOOD DINING TABLE covered in a THICK LAYER OF DUST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAVIER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for a response. Nothing.    She starts to brush the dust off with her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAVIER. I THOUGHT WE TALKED ABOUT TARPING THE FURNITURE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing. So Janine drops her work things, and heads out the side door of the house to a STORAGE AREA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are cans of paint, bags of cement, some tarps. Janine grabs a TARP, when she sees, on a window ledge, next to a folding chair - AN ALUMINUM FOIL ASHTRAY. CIGARETTE BUTTS. AN EMPTY PACK OF AMERICAN SPIRITS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at them for a moment, then heads back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A TORN BUSINESS CARD, TAPED BACK TOGETHER. The name on the card is JARRAD MONTROSE. Gigi sits, staring at the card. She reaches for the phone, and then thinks the better of it. And again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, she grabs the receiver, picks it up, and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Gigi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sits in his office.    He talks into his CELL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi Phillips. I had the - umm - dentist pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry to bug you. I just - I thought you had some really good insights the other night and -- I had a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, maybe I need to be harsh -- Conor is never going to be interested in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I know. This is about - (she looks at the card) - Jarrad. You have a sec?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I meet him at happy hour and he was completely charming --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme guess - he said the only thing happy about this hour is you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He may have used some derivative of that. So, he says he's going to call, but then gave me his card and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know if he called --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But the thing is, I honestly think he's expecting my call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said "Look forward to hearing from you" and not "Look forward to talking to you." I mean, do you hear the connotations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He.   Is.   Not. Interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrone appears in Alex's doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex - this is jacked. The hostess is giving me shit for not wearing a white shirt -- this shirt is WHITE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyrone points to a VERY SMALL WHITE INSIGNIA on an otherwise BLACK SHIRT. Alex shuts the door on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This shit is white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a guy gives you his phone number, instead of taking yours, he's not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took mine first, but then he --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, if a guy wants to see you, he will see you. I once called 55 Lauren Bell's until I got the right one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cute.    What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it turned out, her ass looked really huge in daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it your sensitivity that makes you so popular with women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call him. He doesn't like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again with the sensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.   Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi hangs up, re-tears up Jarrad's card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON:   HAPPY BIRTHDAY MOM written across a CAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the candles are blown out, we widen to reveal: Anna and Conor siting at a cheap picnic table in a tiny backyard, across from MAYA - Anna's mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maya refills her glass from a BOTTLE OF WINE, Anna grabs a GIFT from her bag - hands it to her mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweetie - you didn't have to get me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom - you always say that and I always get you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya takes a BIG SIP OF WINE (not her first) as she tears open the gift, which is clearly a RECORD ALBUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya shows him the album - TIM BUCKLEY'S STARSAILOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim Buckley.    Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here - put on my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna takes the album and heads through the screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Anna ever tell you I knew Tim Buckley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   She did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Song to the Siren" plays as Anna returns to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met at a coffee shop in 1971. Hell's Kitchen. I had no idea who he was. But he had this big mop of hair and these eyes that just looked past you and through you and into you all at the same time. Complete interest and disinterest. It was amazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya pulls out a cigarette and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I was with Anna's father at the time, so, you know...another opportunity missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, please -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the truth. I knew them all. Robert Plant, Harry Nilsson, Graham Parsons... (to Conor) Have you seen the pictures of me from when I was Anna's age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm - I don't think so -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie go get that picture - you know the one -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna just looks at her - pleadingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Your mother's asking you to do something for her on her birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna goes inside.   Maya looks to Conor, takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see - we look strikingly similar. My lips may be a bit fuller, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leans back, puts out her cigarette as Anna returns with A PICTURE. She hands it to Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: MAYA, in her early twenties. Black and white - somewhere in New York. The resemblance to Anna is scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.   That's - unbelievable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's what we're dealing with here, for reference. Imagine meeting someone who looks like that in a coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks down at the picture, then back up to Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny, because, I mean, I guess I kinda did. Anna and I met at a restaurant. That serves coffee. So, not a coffee shop, but...still -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks from Maya to Anna.     Maya stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sweet. But if we're comparing stories - (indicating with her glass) She's no me - and you're no Tim Buckley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, Maya heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone need a refill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks to Conor apologetically.    He just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Conor walk to the front door of her apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks again for coming with me.        You make it so much easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I like your mom.        She's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well - cool's not always what you're looking for in a mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor smiles, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you want another -- foot rub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying.   But it's awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh. I'm just beat. I wanna put on sweats and get in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be into that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna gives him a smile, opens her front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you tomorrow, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a KISS, and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRENT, early 30s, talks to the camera as he drives his Ford Explorer. He's cute - but trying a smidge too hard - - goatee, leather cord necklace he bought in Cancun, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If a girl is into you, she's sleeping with you. And if after a month - two months at the very outside - she's not sleeping with you, she does not like you. I guess the trick is, how to spot this girl early - so you don't waste the one to seven weeks waiting to find out that it's never gonna happen. So, I've got some signs about how to spot this girl - gleaned from my own experience, of course. A girl will never sleep with you if: she calls you cuddly or dependable, she pops a zit in front of you, her name is Amber or Christine, she takes a dump in your bathroom or she takes home leftovers in dates 1-3. I know it's not scientific - but I'm just saying - you were warned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex knocks and opens the door in one motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey dude - you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex heads to the fridge, opens it and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls TWO BEERS out, shuts the fridge and turns to find Conor standing there. He's wearing a REALLY TIGHT, SHINY SHIRT and EVEN TIGHTER, VERY BLUE JEANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or an apple martini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor grabs the beer and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need I ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for work. I'm trying to expand my client base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By pretending you're gay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   By being more gay friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, in real estate terms, by becoming "gay adjacent".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.    I may have to use that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor heads back toward his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna try something else. This may be too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. You dress like that - and you're already seeing a girl who won't sleep with you - I think maybe you can pull it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that she won't sleep with me douchebag...I have slept with her. It's just, you know, she...um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't sleep with you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor reappears, now wearing A FRENCH CONNECTION TYPE TIGHT T-SHIRT AND BLACK JEANS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much, yeah. (re: his new outfit) So, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex gives him the once over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're gonna have to beat 'em away with a stick - you hot, sexy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor rolls his eyes and heads back into his room.    Ale laughs to himself and takes another sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leather couch, framed Orioles jersey - typical bachelor pad. Gigi is making out with GREGORY, 30s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would have thought that a random girl from Pilates would fix me up with such a good kisser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at you sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi beams.   They make out some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to kiss you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm.   We're kissing right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. But next time. The second date kiss is way more intimate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start kissing again -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm going out of town tomorrow - so I'll be out of touch for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gregory starts pulling off Gigi's top.    Gigi pulls away deftly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me a quick second?    Too many diet cokes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi makes a beeline down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi dials her CELL as she goes through Gregory's bathroom cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is also mid-makeout on his leather couch with a HOT WOMAN. The PHONE RINGS. Alex grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry to bug you again.   Quick question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his hot lady) Would you excuse me a second, babe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex walks into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm making out with a guy - PG stuff - and then he mentions he's going out of town, so he's gonna be out of touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe he is going out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To where? The Arab Emirates? Where is he going that he has to be out of touch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi opens the bathroom door and SHOUTS down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going out of town to again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, now what? I'm just supposed to run from every guy who doesn't like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh - yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not going to be anyone left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, I don't know why I'm saying this - but I actually think I know a nice guy who you might like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's a friend of my brother's. Bill. We'll all meet for a drink - it'll be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I'm in his bathroom right now.   What do I now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
