dialogues.text: You gotta come out eventually. But I'd really take my time. Let him sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Gigi finds some Crest Whitestrips and - with determination - decides to APPLY THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's rolling up mats, etc. as a sweaty Ben approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, we ran into each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You came to my class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know it was your class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called and asked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you didn't call me back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you said not to call back if it was my class. Which it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben recommits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran into each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally. A couple of innocent folks - by happenstance - doing their daily workout near one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.   Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Anna picks up her bag and walks past him -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben watches her go, not sure she's serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big indoor pool. Clearly closed, lights off.    Anna open the door with a KEY, Ben follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking - why can't we be friends? Am I not allowed to make friends anymore? Am I not allowed to be friends with hot people? What kind of reverse prejudice is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you. Am I supposed to not be friends with a guy just because he's married, and happens to have this insane smile and this ass that makes me want to dry hump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I just fell in love.   A girl who talks about a dry hump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classy, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classy is lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits at the edge of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, friends, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, Anna pulls off her top. And then her sweats. And, totally naked, slides into the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.   I don't trust myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   You can just watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be the best friend I've ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna LAUGHS, and then dunks her head under the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben comes in the front door, drops his gym bag. Janine sits on the couch flipping through a magazine. He leans in to kiss her on the cheek. She does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey - you smell different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben pulls back smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's an odd thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.    He tries to coolly meet her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's the ashtray and cigarettes I found. In the side yard. What part of "my dad died of lung cancer" is hard for you to wrap your brain around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not lie to me, Ben.      Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious? We have like eight thousand undocumented workers in this house daily. You find cigarettes, and you automatically assume they're mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm not lying. And you are really freaking out. I think the renovation is getting to you because nothing is going on. Just please - relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben walks away.    Off Janine, wanting to believe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben walks to a boat at the end of the dock. He stands, unsure, before deciding to KNOCK on the side of the boat. NEIL emerges - unshaven, possibly unshowered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.     My first visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boat is sick. How come you never invited me out before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this was supposed to be just for Beth and I - for our retirement. Leave our jobs. Sell the house. Take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil is clearly having a tough time. Ben doesn't know what to say. They're silent for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Where are my manners? Permission to board granted. I'll show you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben smiles, steps on to the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A cigarette being lit. WIDEN to reveal Neil smoking on the upper deck of his boat, steering it out into the bay.   Ben stands across from him, looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: cigarette) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil switches to his left hand, away from Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Janine sent you to check on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.    Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any message from Beth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben shakes his head no.    Neil seems disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's been busy getting ready for her sister's funeral though, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her sister's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wedding.    Her sister's wedding.   What did I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil is now LAUGHING HARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I didn't. Shit, did I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil LAUGHS HARDER.    Even Ben sees the humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marriage thing is weird, man. I never thought Beth would give me an ultimatum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?     Why not?   That's what women do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I forgot. That's how Janine got you to bite the bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil looks at Ben, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you regret it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're happy? You'd say you're happily married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks at Neil as if he's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Janine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil takes a drag and looks out over the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN down one of the long tables to find Beth, SMACKING a crab with a mallet. HARD. AND LOUD. The others at the table turn to look at her, annoyed. And that's when we see - there seems to be a party and SPEECH underway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I know when my cousin Paige says those vows tomorrow, there are going to be hearts breaking all over the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth's sister, Paige, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, keep in mind, her sister Beth is still on the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cousin WINKS at Beth.   Beth goes white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, she's an older model, but she's still got a lot of miles left in her. But don't stay on the lot too long, Bethie, or next year's models will --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KEN MURPHY, 60s, nearly tramples guests to grab the mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK - that's enough of the speeches. Time to eat. So enjoy the crab. And the yellow stuff is not hot mustard, it's the crab's hepatopancreas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mixed reaction from the crowd as Ken puts the mic down. He starts to return to his table - when he sees Beth trying to make a sneaky exit. He catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethie, your cousin Jay has always been a jackass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.    And even he's married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you'll get married a little bit later than some people. Big deal. You never did anything the way every one else did it, and that's what I've always thought was so great about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your oldest daughter, and I'm the only one not married. If this was Fiddler on the Roof you'd have to sacrifice me or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ken laughs and puts his arm around Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, look. When everyone else was just going to camp at the Y, you borrowed my New York Times, found some arts camp in the Berkshires, wrote away for information, then got accepted on your own. You were nine. You never did things the way everyone else did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because that's you.   That's why you're my favorite daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth's eyes go WIDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you're supposed to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't give a shit. I'm retired, and I'll say what I want. I'll say it into the mic if you want --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They HUG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sits sipping a drink, alone, when Alex comes in the door and goes directly to her table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. I like a little time before a blind date - prepare myself mentally, remind myself not to tell the story about my molars --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex motions to the WAITRESS to bring them another round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't wait to hear that story about the molars, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can he already not like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I screwed up. I told Bill it was Thursday, but I meant Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi is disappointed. The waitress drops off their drinks. They toast - then observe the SCENE AT THE BAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome. I'm stuck here with a guy who can't distinguish Tuesday from Thursday - and meanwhile this girl - (motions to GIRL at the bar) - she's probably meeting her soul mate as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL is standing between TWO GUYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the guy trying to work the Tom Cruise thing. She's interested. He's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot tell from a cursory glance that he's not interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I can. I manage a restaurant. I see this stuff go down every night. Watch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if on cue, Tom Cruise Guy BANGS his elbow into the GIRL, hard, causing her to spill her drink. Tom Cruise Guy sees, but doesn't acknowledge. Alex looks smug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you have a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And check out droopy dawg on her other side. He can buy her drinks all night, and she'll insist there's no "spark."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there isn't.   You need a spark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "spark" thing is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?    Enlighten me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys invented the "spark" so they could not call and treat you kind of bad and keep you guessing, and then convince you that the anxiety and fear that it creates in you is actually a "spark." And you all buy it. You love it. You all thrive on it because you all love drama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? So you don't wait until the last minute on deadlines, or on phone bills, because you love the drama of not knowing whether you'll make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And let me guess - when you were stalking Conor that night - were you obsessing about him calling for days, even though the date was just kind of mediocre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, you thrive on drama. You gotta be more like me - if a girl likes me great, if not, there are plenty more like her - probably with smaller pores and bigger implants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue drinking and observing the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you sharing all this inside dating information with me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.    I like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start doodling my name on your binder. I just mean, I like you, like I like basset hounds. They're kinda pathetic - so you want to cheer them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again with the sensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex smiles at her.   Gigi can't help but smile back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine walks down the hallway, with JAVIER (40, stocky), her contractor. She's inspecting the crown molding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine stops and looks at Javier.   He looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier, if I asked you an honest question, do you think you could give me an honest answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Because I think some of your guys have been - smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine looks at Javier.    It's awkwardly silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.    It seemed like a statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question part was implied -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't really hear it in the inflection-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier - have your guys been smoking or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. My guys don't smoke on the job site. They're all good guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure your guys aren't sneaking around here? And smoking? And lying to me? And -- smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's starting to freak Javier out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to be honest with me, Javier. Because I can't have someone lying to me. To my face. Under my roof. On my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very softly) That's a lot of prepositions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine does not hear him, and barrels on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, there is no reason for that kind of dishonesty, is there? IS THERE? I mean, we made promises to one another --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier looks at her - what the hell is she talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is, we had a contract. Which is like making promises to each other, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I should just get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Fine.    Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, we're good here, right?     Me and you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blank stare from Javier.    Janine slaps on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, great.     The molding really does look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javier gives a forced smile, and heads back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO WELL BUILT MEN (SKIP and LARRY) sip from bottles of Volvic water as they wander through a kitchen, inspecting the cabinetry. Conor comes into to frame, wearing a toned down version of his "gay friendly" clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, my name is Conor. Please sign in whenever you get a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to a guest book on the kitchen island - next to which Anna stands. Conor joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is insane. You're like the Liza Minelli of real estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.    Your friend Mary's a genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is TEEMING WITH GAY COUPLES - opening closets, admiring floors, munching on complimentary cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.   Gotta run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no.   Just some stuff.    See you later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor goes in for a HUG, but Anna's not ready for it - so he just ends up grabbing her. It's awkward. She leaves, Conor tries to play it off, looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip and Larry look at him sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's holding out on you, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I get your meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's obvious. She won't sleep with you. It's written all over your puppy dog face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor looks at them, decides not to fight it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's killing me. Literally.     I'm dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip and Larry move closer, Larry grabs a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, have a cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just - I have no idea what she's doing. I cannot read her signals - at all. We used to sleep together - all the time. Well, that's not true, I don't know why I said that, it wasn't all the time. But it did happen - I know I'm not making this up. And then, out of nowhere, it stops. But she still calls, she stops by, she sleeps on my couch, she wants a massage, she leaves cute messages - but it never goes ANYWHERE. I mean, what is she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly - we may not have the best insight. Gay signals have nothing to do with straight signals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. Like - here's "I want to sleep with you".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Larry.   Larry looks back at him.    They don break their gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three - that's it.   Three seconds or more - it's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's "I don't want to sleep with you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip look at Larry again.   Larry meets his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two - (he looks away) No. Thanks for playing.    Move along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. That's no help at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But listen - I can tell you this. Gay or straight, you're not going to get anywhere by being inactive. She clearly likes you - maybe she just wants you to be a man and do something. So the next time you're in the position - don't take no for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip looks at Larry, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like felonious advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. Let me rephrase.    Don't take maybe for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor takes this in - that's not a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cute studio apartment. And Ben is in the bed. Anna walks in from the bathroom, in a robe. Ben watches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.   Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.   This is bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna BEAMS.   She joins him in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lying here watching you and I seriously have never felt this way before. I have to forcibly make my brain stop thinking about you. I mean, all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Ben.    He's not smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't do stuff like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuff like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like having sex with women who are not my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, I'm not women.   I'm just one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's second of all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have a second of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought second of all was going to make me feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second of all - I can't stop thinking about you, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other for a LONG MOMENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's eyes light up, but she tries to cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to push you to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be with you. And I can't do that if I'm lying to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what's best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ben pulls her to him, she lets a smile take hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOUIS, 60's, with a kind but very wise face, talks to the camera in his FORMAL DOORMAN attire, standing in front of a posh Upper East Side building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the thing - my daughter is happily married with kids and running a tanning salon on Staten Island. But if she wasn't, I'd tell her the same thing I'd like to tell a lot of the girls that come in and out of this building on the arm of a married guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And here is that advice --- get stocks, cash, annuities, a deed in your name. Don't settle for flowers and a shopping spree at Bendel's. Think to the future. We all know that none of these guys is gonna leave his society wife and let her keep half the money and the classic eight on Park Avenue. So, I wanna tell these young ladies, as long as you only have the guy for a finite period of time -- get something that can last. Because I guarantee you - he won't. And that's the best fatherly advice I can give.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary and Anna, in sweats and Ugg boots and dirty hair, both load their carts with cheap beauty products.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not picking out china patterns or anything - but I've never felt anything like this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy. I can't believe he's gonna leave his wife for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not leaving his wife for me. He's just - he's a good guy. And he can't really explore what we could be if he's lying to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's kind of leaving his wife for me. Is this crazy? This is totally crazy. We barely know each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.   Remember Becca, my sister's friend. Some guy waits on her at Bennigan's - by the end of the night they both knew they had found the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're totally right.   It can happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what about texter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Texter has yet to make any verbal contact. I mean, this guy could have had surgery that left him without a voice box, breathing through a stoma, and I'd never know because I never actually hear his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt he has a stoma -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point. The point is - I can't text. I'm not charming via text. My sarcasm doesn't come through, I can't type fast enough on the little phone keyboard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not just texting. It's email and voicemail and snail mail -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just mail -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever. None of it's working. I've had a guy leave a voicemail for me at work, and then I call him back at home, and he emails me to my Blackberry, and then I text him to his cell and then he emails me to my home account from the plane phone -- and it just totally gets out of hand. I miss the days where you had one phone number with one answering machine that housed one cassette tape and either the cassette tape had a message from the guy or it didn't. That's it. Now you have to go around checking all your portals and get rejected by seven different technologies. It's exhausting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna, who is trying a different shade of nail polish on each finger, calmly looks up at Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what about the singer guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jude.    Yeah, I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally.     I felt like we connected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sits on the couch, wrapped in a blanket, eating graham crackers and watching SOME KIND OF WONDERFUL on TV. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even in the office we can hear the din of the bar scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey.     You're home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.    It's Saturday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't let me go out with guys who don't like me. It's kind of limiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just calling to let you know - I'm having a party at my place next weekend. You should come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Won't Conor be there? Might be kinda awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in DC for the weekend at some real estate conference. But there's gonna be a bunch of single guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I will have plenty of chances to be awkward. Thank god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll be there.      I'll talk you through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the party - is it like a big party, more of a mellow hang or --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CRASH outside Alex's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, OK. Gotta go - I think someone just dropped 84 wine glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi hangs up, and goes back to watching her movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: The TV screen as Mary Stuart Masterson (as WATTS) and Eric Stoltz (as KEITH) hang out in a garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda Jones is no minor leaguer who'll be swept off her feet at the touch of your amateur lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cool. I was just gonna work on it with you but - if you're comfortable...great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.   How do you work on it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretend I'm a girl, OK?    I mean, pretend I'm her...Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sits up. A light bulb has gone off. As she watches Keith and Watts kiss on screen, a smile crosses her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi blows in, dumps her things and turns to Janine:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's into me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awesome. I knew it. (she hugs Gigi) Who's this now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex. It's totally clear to me now. He's Watts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Some Kind of Wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, isn't Mary Stuart Masterson Watts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, why aren't you Watts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Eric Stoltz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is Watts because Watts helps Eric Stoltz go on a date with Amanda Jones, but really she's in love with Eric Stoltz herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - so who's Amanda Jones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess Conor at first. Now men in general. But that's not the point.    The point is -- he's into me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I knew there had to be a reason he was spending all that time with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! It's so obvious now -- there are so many signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh, gimme the signs.   I love to hear about the signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine rolls her chair closer to Gigi's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first they were small - like when I first called he said "Good to hear from you" -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally good sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right? And then the next time I called he was with a woman - but he still took the call. And talked to me for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it was a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called her "babe."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy does not leave a woman - to talk to another woman - unless there's something going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! And it gets more obvious. I mean, please - there was no guy he was going to fix me up with. The fix up was him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shows up - without this fictitious Bill character - and the two of us basically have a date. And then he calls me to invite me to a party at his place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. He so likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine rolls her chair up to Gigi's computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's look up places for your destination wedding. Would you guys wanna do Napa Valley - I've always wanted to go there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi laughs but doesn't fight as Janine starts searching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary sits at her desk, surrounded by her gays.    They ar all looking at her computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way he's already called - we only met for coffee last night. I mean we video iChatted. While holding coffee. Kinda like having coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan hands her the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call your voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he told me he had a gig last night, so he probably got in real late. Did I tell you he was singer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary cradles the receiver with her shoulder and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary hits the SPEAKERPHONE button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SINGING, in a sexy voice) Maaaary. Mary, Mary, Mary, Maaaary.   Oh my Maaary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary is clearly charmed.    The gays all SWOON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other guys shush him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Mary, it's Jude. Just wanted to tell you again how special it was to meet you. So, call me back. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEEP.    Mary BEAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing.    He'll sing to your babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary basks in the attention.       Then, ANOTHER BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SINGING, from speakerphone) Jeeeeny. Jenny, Jenny, Jenny, Jeeeeny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All heads whip around at stare at the SPEAKER PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jenny, it's Jude. Just wanted to -- oh shit, - what number did I call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOME RUSTLING NOISES, and a HANG UP, followed by a dial tone. Mary stares at the phone - then pushes a BUTTON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALL MESSAGES DELETED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all head wordlessly back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: TWO SEEMINGLY IDENTICAL PLANKS OF WOOD. We pull back to reveal Ben and Janine, in the wide aisle of Home Depot, as Janine really studies the two pieces of wood. Finally, she POINTS to one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   That's the laminate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one isn't real hardwood floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But it looks exactly the same - at like one one hundredth of the cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still wanna go with the real wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't even tell the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't like the way it's pretending to be wood. If you're not wood, then don't try to look like wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's pretending --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben is making light.   But Janine is all business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lie. Just be up front - tell people what you really are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben takes this in.   His cheeks start to burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I'm sorry.      You're totally right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK. Maybe we should look at the grills and come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she starts to steer their giant cart away, Ben just stands there, fused to the ground. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I slept with someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine stops, doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't turn to face him.     Total silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me this in Home Depot because you know how I hate a public scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not why I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.     I KNEW IT.   You asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.    I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's you that's been smoking, too, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   Why does that matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine turns to Ben.    She is IRATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAVE - YOU - BEEN - SMOKING?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   No.    I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine just STARES AT HIM, FUMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I talked to Neil, and he said I could stay on his boat for a while if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Janine's eyes go wide with disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXCUSE ME? And now you want to move out? You're like - what - leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben looks confused, but is trying to roll with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. NO. I just assumed that you wouldn't want me to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to deal with this? We're not going to figure out a way to work through this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just assumed that once I told you, you would want me -- out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost a whisper) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads down the aisle with the cart. Ben follows, confused - that didn't go how he thought it would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lush grounds surrounding a beautiful turn-of-the- century mansion. The procession of a wedding has just begun. TWO ADORABLE FLOWER GIRLS start things off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Beth's sister, Laura, processes down the aisle with her husband, STEVEN. Beth's sister Catherine and her husband GEORGE are next. Big smiles all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Beth appears at the end of the aisle with her escort - BUDDY, a 12 year old CHOCOLATE LAB, wearing a coral bow tie. Beth forces a smile as she processes with Buddy - who stops to piss on a chair leg. Beth is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavish reception. Beth takes her seat next to DAN, 40s. Dan looks over at Beth's place card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard a lot about you from Paige. I'd been lobbying for weeks to be seated next to her single sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? So you are - (looks at his placecard) Dan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm actually a wiccan.    So I have a magickal name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Brother Phoenix East-Horse. But I didn't know if that would fit on a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth slaps on a fake smile, and grabs for the wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PARTY is in full swing. Typical affair for someone in their late 20's - mediocre food but decent alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi stands, somewhat uncomfortably, near the Chex Mix. She tries smiling at a TALL GIRL, who ignores her. So Gigi continues absently and compulsively shoving handfuls of Chex Mix into her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes your breath stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi looks up to see Nathan and Bruce - Mary's gay coworkers who are now decked out in full-on Saturday night gay mode - standing next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chex Mix. I learned the hard way. I made out with a guy after eating like a bag of the stuff. He said my breath smelled like trout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi puts her handful of Chex Mix back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That was rude. And that guy I made out with was a total asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to smell you?   I'm sure you don't smell like trout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   I'm good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cups her hand and surreptitiously checks her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Nathan.   This is Bruce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi.   How do you guys know Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't. Our friend Mary heard about it from some guy named Conor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi smiles in recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope - I mean I'm pretty sure - something is about to happen between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're here as like a guest, or like his date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate that - when you don't know if you're a date - so you don't know if you should bring a friend, or if you're like co-hosting or if you should stay til the end to have alone time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a look of DOUBT sweeps across Gigi's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't really say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reflexively GRABS FOR THE CHEX MIX and starts gorging on it again. Nathan stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm sure I'm more than just a guest. I mean - there have been signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did get a slight waft of trout, though. Take a mint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches in his pocket.    Gigi looks at him gratefully

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is over. The dance floor is crowded. The bride, Paige, is out there. Beth's dad is dancing with her mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth's dad gives Beth a wink as she heads onto to the dance floor with DOMINIC, 50s and fat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, where's Neil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We actually broke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. You guys were together for like ten years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.   But yes, a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad cousins can't marry, huh?    Cuz then we could maybe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eeew Dominic, gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth swats Dominic on the arm, and he laughs. And then they are distracted by a COMMOTION ON THE DANCE FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has stopped dancing. They are looking to the floor, near the band. Beth pushes her way through to see-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed. Gigi is smashed into a hallway, trying to look relaxed. Alex comes up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea it would be such a madhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi turns to him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   Great party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are any guys hitting on you? Do you need me to evaluate their level of interest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were gay. Even I know that their level of interest was probably low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - too bad Bill couldn't make it. I still think you guys would hit it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi smiles knowingly - on to Alex's scam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh OK.  Right. (air quotes) "Bill".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex doesn't know how to take that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway - I'm on my way to put out some more liquor. But it looks like the food could use some refreshing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the FOOD TABLE.     Everything is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind helping? I mean, just refill the chips and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, kind of like --- co-hosting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi LOOKS ELATED.   Alex looks CONFUSED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh, OK.   The chips are on top of the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away.   Gigi smiles BIG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is now even more crowded. Gigi weaves her way through the crowd. She's deftly holding SIX DRINKS, passing them off to various people as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops at the food table, rearranges a few bowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She CATCHES ALEX'S EYE across the room, he's talking to friends. She smiles and gives a THUMBS UP. He gives an awkward thumbs up back and returns to his conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi is in the kitchen, mixing up some DIP. She chats with a couple of PARTY-GOERS, very much at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really great party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. When Alex said he wanted to have a party, I was like "Let's do it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks so much for having us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.   Anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attractive TALL GIRL enters the kitchen, and starts LOOKING IN THE CUPBOARDS. Gigi watches with interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you find something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tall Girl finds a BOWL in the cabinet, and grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's OK. I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She brings the bowl over to the counter, and starts emptying Gigi's dip into the bowl. Gigi is THROWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for mixing that up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex asked me to get the dip together. Thanks for getting it started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi's face grows red.   The Tall Girl tastes the dip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm - could use a little more dill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then the Tall Girl deftly grabs the dip, and chips, and heads back out to the party. Gigi looks to the confused party-goers, not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruce and Nathan wave to Gigi as they leave. People are getting coats - the crowd is definitely thinning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi spots Alex in the kitchen and makes a beeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When someone's underwear ends up in your toaster oven - it's been a good party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks at the toaster oven and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess people had fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the TALL GIRL emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, you want me to start cleaning up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi STARES DAGGERS AT HER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sweet of you. But I thought I'd stick around, so I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tall girl shoots Gigi a dirty look as she grabs a trash bag. Gigi grabs one, too. Alex looks mystified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock yourselves out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is really late. Everyone's gone - except the TALL GIRL and ALEX, who sit on the couch playing a NBA LIVE on the XBOX. Gigi enters from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've rounded up the last of the beer bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tall girl and Alex do not look up from the game. Gigi stands there awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, umm - what game is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ignore her.   She looks around.    It's awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I should just -- you know -- I mean it's past three and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YES!!    Suck it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex tosses down his controller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are sensational.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tall girl beams.   Gigi flinches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say it's past three?     Man, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi suppresses a SMILE. The Tall Girl gives Alex a hug, and heads out. Gigi, finally alone with Alex, sits next to him on the couch. They're silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for staying and helping clean up - but I really gotta get to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that an invitation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. That was cheesy.      I'm not good at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then -- before Alex knows what's happening, Gigi is LUNGING at him. She puts his face in her hands, and starts to KISS HIM. REALLY KISS HIM. Finally, Gigi pulls away. She looks breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks a little afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew it. The best relationships grow out of friendships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes in to kiss him again.   This time he stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummmm....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you and I are in a relationship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd say if we're not at relationship station--ship, we're at least on the track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex gets up off the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why would you think that, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there were - you know - signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummm - it was good to hear from me. You talked to me even when you were with a girl. I felt something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She trails off.   Alex is not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? What have I been saying since I met you? If a guy wants to date you HE WILL MAKE IT HAPPEN. HE WILL ASK YOU OUT. DID I ASK YOU OUT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were Watts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex doesn't even hear her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do women do this? Why do they build this stuff up in their minds, take each little thing a guy does and twist it into something else --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi stands there, embarrassed, taking Alex's berating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather be like that - than like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I dissect each little thing, and put myself out there too much, and maybe I even thrive on the drama of it all-- but at least that means I still care. You think you've won because women are expendable to you? Sure, you don't get hurt or make an ass of yourself that way, but you don't fall in love that way, either. You haven't won, Alex. You're alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi grabs her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may do a lot of stupid shit - but I know I'm a lot closer to finding someone than you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi turns and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi looks at the phone, and then finally DIALS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Janine, I'm sorry it's so late, but I just - don't start picking out your bridesmaid dress, OK? I know this isn't the first time this has happened, it's just - this one wasn't about whether he liked me. I just really liked him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi hangs up, lays on the bed, snaps off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ken Murphy, Beth's dad, lies in bed, in a Notre Dame sweatshirt, with papers, and books surrounding him. Beth clears his breakfast dishes off of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Less of that cardboardy brown stuff. More regular people food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cardboardy brown stuff is called whole grain bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you could just fry me up a couple sausage links?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People who have just had heart attacks generally are not advised to eat animal fat, stuffed in synthetic casings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ken looks at her, with a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I tell you that you're not only my favorite daughter, but you're also the prettiest? So much better looking than those other dogs. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna work this time.   But I appreciate the effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth takes his dirty dishes and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth hauls the dishes downstairs and through the den where Steven, Laura's husband, is on the couch, intently watching the golf channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Beth. Grab me a beer if you're going that way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a little plate of cold cuts if there are any left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth just keeps on walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth walks by Paige, on the couch, and DEVON, Paige's new husband, on the floor, surrounded by a mess of VINYL RECORDS. He has an old BOBBY DARIN tune BLARING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might wanna kill the volume just a smidge. My mom is finally taking a nap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think your dad really wants to hang on to all this vinyl? My collection could use a bunch of these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it the fuck down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Devon and Paige look at her, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen is a total MESS. Beth sets the dishes down in a precarious pile of other dishes, and sees her sisters Laura and Catherine at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finally got mom to lay down in the spare room. All we have left to eat is some old jelly and ramen noodles, so after I tackle some of these dishes, maybe we can go to the store. Our new brother is trying to co-opt dad's property before he's even dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Laura, your husband would really like a beer to go with his fifth consecutive hour of the golf channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth looks up. Laura is pointing to Catherine, who has her head in her hands. She's CRYING SOFTLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK.     It's all gonna be OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do without dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, he's upstairs watching 'Oprah After The Show'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And second of all - you have us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's always been - the one who's there for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your husband?    Where the hell is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing ultimate frisbee.    His team may make the quarterfinals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth rolls her eyes.    The DISHES crash in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine sits at Beth's desk, across from Gigi, who stares at her in disbelief. Janine fiddles with a TILE SAMPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head "no") It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you going to - leave - him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi, he's my husband. He's not just some guy that didn't call me back. And he did admit it to me. He didn't wait to get caught. That takes courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi is clearly STUNG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean that.     I know Alex was not just some guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm willing to accept my responsibility in this. I forced him into getting married. He wasn't ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine - this is not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is.  I've - changed. I used to be fun. I was fun when we met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BEAT.   Janine looks at Gigi, the tears come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never have sex anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of couples got through lulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We never have sex. Realistically, what did I expect him to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that's really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at the TILE in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is too small. I gotta tell Javier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This tile. I gotta go.    Tell Beth I took a personal day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine grabs her purse, heads out as Gigi looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIEL (50's, highly manicured, upper class type) sits on a yacht in what looks to be the French Riviera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My first husband was unimpressive. I found him in bed with his big breasted secretary when I came home early from the Maldives. So unoriginal, it made me feel sorry for him. My second husband was a pinch more creative. Cheated on me with my sister - but made me believe that I was insane for being suspicious. At last - some intrigue, some mind games - though my sister's two year old eventually gave them up. But my last husband -- he was a gem. A veritable master at covering his tracks. I poured over his phone records, intercepted his credit card bills, had him followed on countless occasions - and never found a single shred of evidence. It wasn't until he died that I found out about the property he owned with his Austrian mistress. But the real master, I have to say -- is me. Three husbands -- countless boyfriends, and I haven't been caught yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna SQUEEZES Ben's hand as they stride down the hallway to his office. Anna is trying to suppress a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben smoothly EXTRICATES his hand from Anna's.   He nods t COWORKERS as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was all you, babe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben smiles at Anna, as they round the corner of the corridor to his office. He goes in, and she follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben deftly shuts and locks the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OH.    MY.   GOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot believe this. He liked my demo. Did you hear what he said? When he said it was hauntingly beautiful? Did you hear that part?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.    I was sitting right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben smiles, and pulls Anna to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.     Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, they start to KISS. It gets heated. CLOTHES START TO COME OFF. MOSTLY ANNA'S. They make their way over to the LEATHER SOFA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it that every time I see your body, I'm shocked at how beautiful it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna smiles at the compliment. She starts to work on his shirt when: SOMEONE TRIES TO OPEN THE LOCKED DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana, I need to go over the offering statement. Can I get a few minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben continues to remove his shirt as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Dana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEN FREEZES.    Literally freezes on top of Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben FRANTICALLY puts his hands over Anna's mouth. Then, working with speed and precision, he GATHERS ALL OF ANNA'S THINGS and shoves her - NAKED - into the CLOSET. There isn't enough room to stand, so she has to sit. She looks up at Ben, he closes the closet door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to the door of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. I told Dana to get this lock fixed. One sec.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you even lock it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben re-buttons his shirt, gives the office a once over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never get anything done if I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Ben opens the door, and Janine is standing there, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a show of CLOSING AND LOCKING THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben goes to sit behind his desk, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine, clearly a little nervous, goes to straddle Ben at his desk chair. Her skirt is way too long to do this, so she has to regroup, and hike up the skirt. Ben glances over at the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just thought - maybe we could, you know, relight the fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, did you hear what I just said? I gotta get this offering statement out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben picks up some papers, but Janine is not giving up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I am trying here. Do you want to save our marriage or don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine looks at Ben.   Ben is SILENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits, holding back tears, as she listens closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll let me do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then a ZIPPER OPENING, a chair CREAKING -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just like that, yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HOLD ON Anna as she sits there, stonefaced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex has the staff (of about 10) assembled for the pre- shift meeting. He consults a clipboard as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK - Tyrone you bus 4 through 6 - and pitch in with the servers when you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...I'm on 8 thru 10. I'm always on 8 through 10. Been working here 18 months doing 8 through 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   Luis you take 4 through 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff looks at each other - perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude.    Luis quit like 10 months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex rifles through his papers, not sure what he's looking for. He slams his clipboard on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we even need to have this meeting? Seriously? Does this serve any purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group voice their opinions - a resounding "NO".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.   Great. Get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group disperses, Alex heads around the bar.   He sees Kelli Ann walking away and calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Kelli Ann - any calls for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since you asked me 11 minutes ago?   No, not a lot of phone traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelli Ann starts to turn away as she sees Alex grab his cell phone, look at it, then put it down. He grabs a beer, takes a swig - then grabs his cell phone again - staring at it, willing it to ring. He puts it down again. A HUGE SMILE grows on Kelli Ann's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happened to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has happened to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex takes his beer and heads down the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't hide it man. I know strung out and you are strung - out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is amazing. Can't focus, right? Jumping every time your phone rings, checking your email 100 times a day. Wishing you could write songs. Feeling the need to bring up her name in random conversations...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex stops at the office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always the same. And it has happened to you, my friend. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks at Kelli Ann, her words settling in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kelli Ann smiles, and as she walks away -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to my world asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex takes this in, KNOWING SHE'S RIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine, now fully dressed, hovers by the door.       Ben back at his desk, eyes on his computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure I can't interest you in a little beef and broccoli? I'm treating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really gotta get this stuff done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine is clearly flailing.      She starts to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.   I'll see you at home.     I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Ben.    He has no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering his anger) I love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janine leaves. As soon as she's gone, Ben gets up, shuts the office door - and goes to the closet - when the door FLIES OPEN IN HIS FACE - NEARLY SMASHING HIM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no choice. What was I supposed to do when she -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make me sick to my stomach.    You are a disgusting excuse for a man -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pulls her clothes back on in a FURY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to do it, Anna. You know that it's you I want to be with -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts out a hand to try to touch her.    She RECOILS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? You will never lay a hand on me again. I may just be a piss poor girl from Dundalk who works at a gym - but I am so too good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi sits on her couch, a pile of BILLS in her lap - most of which say LATE, OVERDUE, etc. She's on the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dino, thank you again for letting me pay over the phone. I assure you this late payment thing will never happen again. Yep -- just trying to trim some of the drama out of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my other line.   OK.     B-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi CLICKS OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Gigi.    This is Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ummm -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex's friend. We were supposed to meet up - but Alex told me the wrong day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gigi lets this sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill.    So you do exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. And I'd love to buy you dinner sometime if you're game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.    Sure.   Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts on a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna stands in the cluttered kitchen of her mom's house. She writes out a CHECK, leaves it on the counter. She looks to the living room, where Maya sleeps on the couch. She watches her for a second, struggling with a blanket, before heading over to her. She crouches next to the couch, helps her adjust the blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go. I left the check on the counter. It should at least get you through this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya opens her eyes and looks up at her, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks sweetie. I don't know what I would do without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya closes her eyes again. Anna sits there, watching her. Anna's eyes start to fill with tears - quietly, she begins crying. Maya finally notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby - what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya struggles to sit up and hug her. Anna sits next to her on the couch, still trying to get it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it money? Because you can take back the check if -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not that. I mean - yes, I'm broke - but it's not that. It's just - (tearing up again) I'm just so lost mom. I've been seeing this guy - who is exciting and amazing and thoroughly unavailable. I thought he was - the one - but he turned out to be such an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya nods, almost smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then there's -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who I'm so horrible to. But he takes it. And he's - there. Waiting. But I just don't want to - I don't know -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle?   Like you think I did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks at her mother, guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, your father and I had a glorious life together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? All you talk about are the things you didn't do, the people you wish you could have been with, the Tim Buckleys - anything but the life you actually had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya looks at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are just dreams Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna tries to process this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now true - I did not like your father at all when we met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or after we got married for that matter. But let me tell you this - life with him was a hell of a lot better than life is without him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya stands, walks slowly toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are worse things in life than settling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like wishing you had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna lays on her bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell RINGS, Anna gets up to answer it. Almost as soon as she turns the knob, Conor is standing in the middle of her studio apartment. He is all amped up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches up to give him a hug, he doesn't go for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, why did you call me sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we always call each other that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna doesn't have an answer for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to say something, OK? I mean, we call each other sweetie, and we fall asleep on the phone after talking for hours and I washed your hair for you after you had that shoulder surgery and everything - it's like we're together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that I -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me finish. Maybe it's my fault. Maybe I haven't been clear about what I want. So let me be clear. I love hanging out, but I am so attracted to you, and I just - I want both. I want to make love to you. I know that sounds kind of embarrassing coming out of my mouth - I just freaked myself out, too - but it's true. And I'm not sure what happened, or why we stopped - but I don't really care. I just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conor is STUNNED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about really doing this. Like a full-on relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
